paragraphs.text: Weak-links criterion for pnictide and cuprate superconductors
Weak-links are defects that limit dissipation-free transport current flow in superconductors.
Grain boundaries, nano-and micro-cracks, and planar precipitations of secondary phases are typical examples of weak-links in practical superconductors.
There is an unanswered practical question: is the critical current for a given superconductor limited by weak-links, or does wire fabrication provide a weak-link-free superconductor?
In this paper, we answer this question for layered quasi-two-dimensional (quasi-2D) superconductors, namely pnictides and cuprates.

Our approach is based on the fact that the self-field critical current density in weak-link-free superconductors is J c (sf, T)=A/λ 3 (T), where λ(T) is the London penetration depth and A is the relevant fundamental constant.

Taking into account that the transition temperature, T c , in layered quasi-2D superconductors is limited by the phase fluctuation temperature, T fluc = B/λ 2 (0)1.2•T c , where B is the relevant fundamental constant, then the substitution of λ(0) deduced from the measured J c (sf, T) gives a tool to compare the deduced T fluc and experimentally measured T c .

This provides a simple criterion to reveal the presence or absence of weak-links which has been proven by an analysis of self-field critical currents in a variety of high-temperature superconductors, ranging from atomically thin FeSe up to commercially available tapes of RBa 2 Cu 3 O 7 .
critical currents, iron-based superconductors, HTS
Weak-links are defects in superconductors that limit their critical currents and have a detrimental effect on the engi- neering applications of superconducting wire .
For several decades, the main tool for investigating weak-links in prac- tical wires made using cuprates, and for the last decade using pnictides, have been microscopic techniques .

Despite the ongoing research in this field, it is still unclear how to answer one of the most important questions of wire manu- facture: how do we determine if weak-links are limiting the current carrying capacity of a given superconducting wire?
Here we present an answer to this question for iron-based and cuprate superconductors.

Our approach is based on the recent finding [4] that in weak- link-free thin film superconductors of type-II, the self-field critical current density, J c (sf, T), is described by the equation: where f 0 is the magnetic flux quantum, μ 0 is the magnetic permeability of free space, λ is the London penetration depth, κ=λ/ξ is the Ginzburg-Landau parameter, and ξ is the coherence length. The annotation 'sf' refers to 'self-field'. Equation (1) can be converted to give: For anisotropic superconductors with mass anisotropy γ=(m c /m ab ) 0.5 , where m c and m ab are effective out-of-and in-plane masses respectively, the equation for rectangular conductors is:

We now consider superconductors which contain weak- links. The experimentally measured J c (sf, T) for these part- icular specimens will be lower in comparison with weak-link- free specimens, as weak-links limit transport current flow in superconductors. In this case the deduced λ(0) (by using J c (sf, T) and equations (1)-(4) will be larger for weak-link affected samples than for weak-link-free samples. We note that the actual λ(0) for both types of samples will likely be the same as the presence of weak-links in the material will be unlikely to change λ(0). This is because the superfluid density should remain the same dispite the presence of weak-links, but the restriction of supercurrent flow will lead to lower measured values of J c (sf, T) and thus the deduced λ(0) will be larger than the actual λ(0).

The simplest approach to detect the presence of weak- links in a superconductor is to compare a deduced λ(0) value for a given superconducting wire with λ(0) values already reported for this superconducting material measured by other techniques. However, this approach might not work for many practical cases, for example, in the case of newly discovered materials, atomically thin (and exfoliated) superconductors, and exotic superconductors (like compressed H 3 S [6]). It may be the case for these examples and others that the application of standard techniques to measure λ(0) is questionable, time consuming, or reported λ(0) values are within a large interval as the experimental techniques used are not able to determine λ(0) with great accuracy.
Based on the above, we consider a way to answer the previously posed question for the pnictide and the cuprate superconductors.

It is a well-established fact [7] that the transition temp- erature, T c , of quasi-two-dimensional (quasi-2D) super- conductors (which includes cuprates and pnictides) is limited by the temperature at which phase fluctuations of the order parameter become significant.

The characteristic temperature, T fluc , of these fluctuations is given by Emery and Kivelson [7]: where k B is the Boltzmann constant, and d 001 is the mean spacing between superconducting sheets for quasi-2D sys- tems.

It was shown in the case of the cuprates and pnictides that the relation between T c and T fluc is: If thin films have thickness, 2b, less than the London penetration depth in the c-direction, λ c (0), one can substitute equations (1), (2) into equations (5), (6) and find: This equation provides a simple route to determine if the weak-links in a given superconductor are reducing the experimentally measured J c (sf, T).

If J c (sf, T) has been measured to sufficiently low temperatures, J c (sf, T=0 K) can be extrapolated and a comparison of the calculated T fluc can be made with the experimentally measured transition temperature, T c .
If T fluc is larger than T c , the transport current for that particular superconductor is not limited by weak- links.
If the superconductor is affected by weak-links, then J c (sf, T) will be lower than expected and the calculated T fluc will be smaller than T c .

Equation (7) can also be rearranged to allow calculation of a 'weak-link limit' of J c (sf, T∼0 K) which is given as Here if the observed J c (sf, T∼0 K) is less than J c,2Dfluc (sf, T∼0 K) then the critical current has likely been affected by weak-links in the sample.

The right-hand side of equation is a function of only Within a multiplication pre-factor of the order of unity, equation (8) calculates more or less the achievable J c (sf, T) value for quasi-2D superconductors where the order parameter phase fluctuations determine the observed T c value.

The most direct way to test the proposed criterion (equations (7), (8) is to analyse experimental J c (sf, T) data reported by the same research group on both weak-link-free samples and samples where weak-links have been deliber- ately introduced.

There are several reports available with this type of experimental data, the results of which will be shown to support the proposed criterion (equations (7), (8) for pnictide and cuprate superconductors.

This means that knowledge of κ, d 001 and T c for any quasi-2D superconductor will be enough to make a judgement on the desirability of doing further work to reduce weak-links in the material (which will in general require a very sig- nificant research and development (R&D) investment [9-11]), as equation (8) provides an estimate of the achievable self- field critical current capacity for a given material.
Iron-based superconductors 3.1.1.
Ba(Fe,Co) 2 As 2 .
Katase et al have reported J c (sf, T) data for high-quality epitaxial Ba(Fe,Co) 2 As 2 films (2a=10 μm and 2b=250 nm).
The films were deposited by pulsed laser deposition on single crystals of (La,Sr)(Al,Ta)O 3 LSAT (non- BGB) as well as 30°-[001]-tilted bicrystal (La,Sr)(Al,Ta)O 3 (LSAT) substrates (BGB).

The film thickness was less than the c-axis London penetration depth for Ba(Fe,Co) 2 As 2 , λ c (0)= 1 μm , and thus by substituting the observed T c =22.6 K [12], the distance between FeAs layers, d 001 =0.65 nm , and κ=90 [13, 14] into equation , one can calculate that J we show experimental J c (sf, T) reported by Katase et al for both films.
Also in figure 1 we show J c (sf, T) data for a low quality Ba(Fe,Co) 2 As 2 film which was synthesised and studied by the same research group in a different report .
This low quality film is obviously affected by weak-links as J c (sf, T=4 K)=1.2 MA cm −2 as well as being less than the J c (sf, T=4 K) of the other films.
Mohan et al reported J c (sf, T) data for similar Ba(Fe,Co) 2 As 2 films deposited on MgO single crystals, for which J c (sf, T=2 K)=2.2 MA cm −2 (figure 1).

spans.text: Ba(Fe,Co) 2 As 2 films deposited on MgO single crystals
spans.formattedText: Ba(Fe,Co) <sub>2</sub> As <sub>2</sub> films deposited on MgO single crystals

paragraphs.text: Also, Katase et al reported J c (sf, T) data for Ba(Fe,Co) 2 As 2 films deposited on biaxially textured MgO-buffered metal-tape flexible substrates, where J c (sf, T=4 K)=1.5 MA cm −2 (figure 1), which is just a little higher than the calculated J c,2Dfluc (sf, T∼0 K).
Yuan et al reported J c (sf, T) data for Ba(Fe,Co) 2 As 2 deposited on a CaF 2 single crystal substrate.
These films have a relatively large transition temperature of T c =26 K with a corresponding value J c,2Dfluc =1.7 MA cm −2 .

This is about 50% larger when compared with J c,2Dfluc (sf, T∼0 K) calculated for the other films, however, the experimental J c (sf, T) data for Ba(Fe,Co) 2 As 2 on a CaF 2 substrate (figure 1) is well aligned with the best films on LSAT single crystals.
As we can see in figure 1, our expectation (equation ) that weak-link-free films should have J - firmed by an analysis of the Ba(Fe,Co) 2 As 2 film data.

Experimental J c (sf, T) for Ba(Fe,Co) 2 As 2 films deposited on LSAT single crystal (non-BGB) [12]; on 30°-[001]-tilted bicrystals of LSAT (BGB) [12], and low quality Ba(Fe,Co) 2 As 2 film on LSAT single crystal (LQ) [17].

There are also Ba(Fe,Co) 2 As 2 films deposited on a MgO single crystal (MgO CS) [18], a CaF 2 single crystal (CaF 2 SC) [19] and on a MgO-buffered metal-tape flexible substrate (MgO/metal tape) [20].
Experimental J c (sf, 4 K, θ GB ) for Ba(Fe,Co) 2 As 2 films deposited on MgO and LSAT [001]-tilted bicrystals [22].
Another question to consider is what critical grain boundary angle, θ GB,c , will cause J c (sf, T) to reduce below J c,2Dfluc .
To answer this question in figure 2 we plotted J c (sf, 4 K,θ GB ) data reported by Hiramatsu et al for Ba(Fe,Co) 2 As 2 films.
The observed T c for these films was 19.1 K and an evaluation of equation gives the value J T sf, 0 K 1.05 MA cm .
c,2Dfluc 2 = -  ( ) Based on the experimental data shown in figure 2 we can conclude that θ GB,c =10°.

This result is agreement with a report by Sato et al , who showed that for BaFe 2 (As 1-x P x ) 2 films deposited on poorly aligned (8°) polycrystalline metal-tape substrates, J c (sf, T) does not degrade in contrast with films deposited on well aligned (4°) substrates.

The next iron- based superconductor on which we test our idea is BaFe 2 (As 1-x P x ) 2 deposited on practical ion beam assisted deposition (IBAD)-MgO metal-tape substrates as reported by Hiramatsu et al .
Bulk BaFe 2 (As 1-x P x ) 2 exhibits a significantly higher maximum T c ∼ 31 K [21] when compared with Ba(Fe,Co) 2 As 2 (T c ∼22 K ).
However, thin films on IBAD-MgO metal-tape sub- strates have a lower transition temperature in comparison with bulk samples .

A question can be asked here: are BaFe 2 (As 1-x P x ) 2 films deposited on practical IBAD-MgO metal-tape substrates affected by weak-links or is some other factor playing a role in suppressing the superconducting properties.

To answer this question, we calculate J c,2Dfluc (sf, T∼0 K) for all samples reported by Hiramatsu et al , noting that the change of d 001 versus phosphorus concentra- tion is small [21] and therefore assuming d 001 =0.635 nm for all compositions.
In figure 3 we present the results.
Despite the different film compositions, the ratio of J c (sf, T = 4 K)/J c,2Dfluc (sf, T∼0 K) remains relatively constant at 0.7-0.8 for x0.32.
This suggests that the effect of the weak-links is similar across these films, which is could be due to the use of the same substrate.
The results in figure 3 show that:
1. A further 30%-50% improvement in the critical current is still possible for BaFe 2 (As 1-x P x ) 2 deposited on practical IBAD-MgO metal-tape substrates.

2. The fundamental performance of the wire is better at lower phosphorus concentrations, and it is likely that it will be easier to create weak-link-free superconducting wire with a lower phosphorous content, rather than focusing on higher phosphorous concentrations.
FeSe single/double atomic layer films.
We now turn to a most fascinating iron-based superconductor, FeSe.
Understanding the physics of this chemically simple compound has proven to be a difficult task.

One example of its remarkable properties was discovered by Wang et al , who found that reducing down to a single or double layer of FeSe causes a notable increase in the transition temperature, reaching T c =100 K [26] in the case of a single FeSe atomic layer.
The crystalline structure of FeSe is described elsewhere where the distance between FeSe atomic layers was found to be d 001 =0.553 nm .
It also has a Ginzburg- Landau parameter of κ=72 .
In figure 4 we show J c (sf, T) for a double layer of FeSe reported by Zhang et al with a current bridge width of 2a=1.45 mm.
The observed superconducting transition temperature of this FeSe film was T c =23.5 K .

The J c (sf, T) of this film has already been analysed in our previous paper , with the resulting fit shown in A calculation of the weak-link-free critical current density of this film gives J T sf, 0 K 1.75 MA cm .
The experimental J c (sf, T) data [27] as well as the fit to our model [5, 29] closely match giving J T sfThis means that the atomically thin FeSe films fabricated by

The dependence of J c (sf, 4 K), J c,2Dfluc (sf, T∼0 K) and their ratio for BaFe 2 (As 1-x P x ) 2 (x=0.22−0.42) films grown at the optimum T s =1050°C on practical IBAD-MgO metal-tape sub- strates [24].
Experimental J c (sf, T) (reported in [27]) for a double layer FeSe film. Zhang et al are free of weak-links and the critical current is reaching full capacity in these films.
We now consider the case of a single layer FeSe film with T c =99 K .
By substituting the relevant parameters into equation we obtain J T sf, 0 K 15.1 MA cm .
c,2Dfluc 2 data for this film has been reported by Ge et al and it is shown in figure 5 together with the calculated J c,2Dfluc (sf, T∼0 K).
It can be seen that this state-of-art FeSe film is slightly affected by weak-links as the ratio J c (sf, T=4 K)/J c,2Dfluc (sf, T∼0 K) = 0.86 is less than 1.
Taking into account that J c (sf, T) has an upturn in shape at low temperature, we expect the ratio J c (sf, T)/J c,2Dfluc (sf, T∼0 K) for T<4 K will increase.
The cuprates are another class of quasi-2D superconductors and here we will show the application of our criterion for two commonly studied compounds, Bi 2 Sr 2 Ca 2 Cu 3 O 10+δ and YBa 2 Cu 3 O 7-δ .
Bi 2 Sr 2 Ca 2 Cu 3 O 10+δ .

Hänisch et al have measured the J c (sf, T) of high-quality Bi 2 Sr 2 Ca 2 Cu 3 O 10+δ thin films deposited on [001] tilted SrTiO 3 bicrystals with a misorientation angle of θ GB =0°, 8°, 16°, 24°, 26°, 30°, and 36.8°.
The crystalline structure of the Bi 2 Sr 2 Ca 2 Cu 3 O 10+δ phase has been reported on elsewhere [31], and the value d 001 =0.59 nm can be found in .
The model reported in was used to fit the J c (sf, T) experimental data [30] to deduce T c and obtain an extrapolated value for J c (sf, T∼0 K).
To perform this fit we used κ=170
The result of the fit is shown in figure 6 where a value of T c =86±1 K was deduced.

Substituting the values into equation (8) gives J T sfOur fit of the J c (sf, T) experimental data to model [5] gives an extrapolated value of J T sfexcellent agreement with the expectation that a high-quality Bi 2 Sr 2 Ca 2 Cu 3 O 10+δ film deposited on a single crystal should be free of weak-links.
It can also be seen in figure 6 that J c (sf, T) for samples deposited on a STO bicrystal with θ GB =8°is almost three times lower than J c,2Dfluc (sf, T∼0 K).
YBa 2 Cu 3 O 7 .
The influence of grain boundaries on critical currents in YBa 2 Cu 3 O 7 has been extensively studied for decades [32-35].
Here we only demonstrate the remarkable progress in manufacturing commercial REBa 2 Cu 3 O 7 superconducting wires over the last two decades.
YBa 2 Cu 3 O 7 has a distance between CuO 2 planes of d 001 =0.338 nm [36] and a Ginzburg-Landau parameter of κ=95 [4].
Experimental J c (sf, T) (reported in [26]) for single atomic layer FeSe.
Experimental J c (sf, T, θ GB ) data and data fit to BCS-based model [5] for Bi 2 Sr 2 Ca 2 Cu 3 O 10+δ film deposited on STO [001]- tilted bicrystals [30].
Experimental J c (sf, T) data and data fit to our model [5] for a YBa 2 Cu 3 O 7 film deposited on YSZ reported by Widder et al [3].
The J c,2Dfluc (sf, T∼0 K) value is not shown on the graph but stated in the figure.
In we show the result of early work on 2G wire development reported by Widder et al together with a fit of the data to our model .
The YBa 2 Cu 3 O 7 film was deposited on a polished Y 2 O 3 -stabilized ZrO 2 substrate (YSZ).
The transition temperature was deduced to be T c =81.6 ± 0.3 K and an evaluation of equation gives J T sf, 0 K 25.0 MA cm .
c,2Dfluc 2 = -  ( ) It is obvious that the experimental J c (sf, T∼0 K) is more than two orders of magnitude below J c,2Dfluc (sf, T∼0 K) (figure 7).
Widder et al showed in their figure 3 that the YBa 2 Cu 3 O 7 film has a granular structure and the film was strongly affected by weak-links.
In we show experimental J c (sf, T) data for a commercial REBa 2 Cu 3 O 7 wire manufactured by with a fit to our model .
We measured the J c (sf, T) data on a recently developed 1 kA-class cryogen-free critical current characterization system .

It can be seen for this wire, having a transition temperature of T c =88.5 K, that the extrapolated J c (sf, T) value at T∼0 K is more than 30 MA cm −2 which is above the weak-link limit of J T sf, 0 K 28.2 MA cm .

In conclusion, we have proposed a simple criterion to deter- mine the presence or absence of weak-links in layered quasi- 2D superconductors, which was applied to iron-based and cuprate superconductors.
To calculate the limit only the Ginzburg-Landau parameter, transition temperature and 2D layers separation distance are needed.
This approach might be considered as additional useful tool to optimize R&D efforts in developing practical HTS wires.
Experimental J c (sf, T) data for AMCS Amperium wire [11] data with to our model [5].
